The biggest downside to most 3D displays was the limited refresh rate ( most were 60 Hz). Since the 3D effect is achieved by showing each left/right image at alternate frames, 60 FPS content/games would often have weird camera judder. 1080p also didn't help out 3D content, since the resolution of 3D media/games was effectively halved (since it would use the left side for one view, and the right side for the other, then the TV would basically switch between each half of the displayed image). So, 3D content would often look a bit blurier than standard 2D content.
While 120 Hz 3D TVs DO exist, they were INCREDIBLY expensive, and I can honestly say I've never known anyone who had one. Even with calibration, this TV is going to be an exercise in frustration if you're after an accurate image for all content.  Sony doesn't allow for separate calibration settings for SDR and HDR10 signals.  They just take your SDR calibration settings and automatically translate and apply them to HDR10 signals.  While that sounds simpler in theory, it doesn't work very well in practice on this model.  If you share settings like this, your grayscale tracking (especially near black) is going to be terrible.  If you calibrate for accurate HDR, then SDR will have a green tint in darker grayscale shades around 5% gray.  If you calibrate for SDR, then HDR10 will have a red tint.  The only solution is to calibrate a separate picture mode and color temperature for SDR signals and another picture mode and color temperature for HDR10.  Unfortunately, the set won't switch calibration settings automatically based on signal type, so you then need to manually switch between SDR and HDR calibrated settings every time you start watching content.
